turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Here--drop it where they'll find it and return it to him. He's not a bad egg. I'll ship him back the fifty before we arrive.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: You take some awful chances.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Well, I had to get some dough to play with those suckers. Here, get this changed.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: They won't squawk--they're professionals.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Well, if that's the case, you're sure of winning the first couple of hands--But what about after that?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: That's where you come in. Now, listen, Shortie--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Have the purser give you twenty-five hundred dollars for this check--and bring the cash here.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Brett--right away.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Here's your twenty-five hundred, Mr. Brett.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Thank you.  I owe you a dollar forty--here--keep the change.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: I'll take one.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Sorry to interrupt you, Mr Brett, but I have a message for you.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Your mother is feeling seasick and would like to see you right away.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Oh, is she? What a shame!  You'll pardon me?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: About sixteen hundred.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Partners, ain't we?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Sure--and to show you I'm a regular fella--  Here's that twenty-five hundred.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: You keep it--

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: <U>Me</U>!

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Sure! McKinney will never suspect you--

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Say--wait a minute!

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: See you later, Shortie--I'm off to the pool.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Hello, Jimmy. What's up?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Listen, Runt--Quick! Where's the ice?

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Why--I--er thought with all this heat turned on I'd hide it.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Where did you hide it?

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: On the drunk.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Get it!

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: Come in!

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Hope I didn't keep you waiting.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: I'll bet a couple of hundred--  I wonder what's keeping that boy.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: Don't worry about that.  We'll settle after the hand. Out in Montana where I come from a man's word is all that's necessary. What have you got?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Three Jacks.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: That beats two Pairs. I'm glad <U>I</U> didn't win the first pot. Take the money, Mr. Brett.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: It's your deal.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: It's a pleasure.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: How's your mother feeling?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Much better--thank you--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Well, to tell you the truth, gentlemen, I've sworn off playing poker.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: Why, you wouldn't quit when you're ahead, would you?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Why isn't that a good time to quit?

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: I thought you were a sucker--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Think again--

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: That goes two ways.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Make it three, boys--I'll play this hand pat.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I think I've met you before, Mr. Brett.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Oh, yes. On the pier.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Before that. Your face is very familiar.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Yours, too. Are you the McKinney, the dentist on Calumet Avenue in Chicago?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: No--not quite.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: I'm going to the show--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I'll go with you--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Care to join us?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: No, thanks--I never gambled in my life.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: This is exciting--but if it's been stolen they can't get away with it on a ship--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Some of the smartest robberies have taken place aboard ships--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: It'll be very interesting to see how you go about solving this, Inspector--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Sorry--but I'm on a vacation--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: If he lets you down I'll try my hand at sleuthing--  Bet I could find that bracelet--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I wouldn't be surprised--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: I wouldn't worry about it--it'll turn up--  How about a nightcap, Inspector?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: No, thanks--I'll take a walk around the deck and then turn in--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Good night!

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Thought you were going to turn in, Inspector.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Nervous. Couldn't sleep. Feel like a nightcap?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: How about you?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: No, thanks. I've promised to play cards.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: You know what I'd do, if I were you--before the card game I'd go to the Purser's office.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Well, someone else besides myself may have seen you in the vicinity of Mrs. Rosson's cabin this evening--even the stewards in that corridor insisted on being searched. Get me?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Sure, I'll go.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I'll go with you.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Swell!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: It's easy to see the Purser hasn't had much practice.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: How about trying your fine Italian hand?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: This has nothing to do with me--  But always remember, Purser, when you're searching anybody, take the lining of their coat, like this--  --run your fingers all along these seams.... Then-- back of the collar--<U>here</U>--that used to be a favorite trick--and never forget to put your finger down inside of the shoe--like this.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Hey!--you're tickling me.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Then we run our hands down a man's arms and legs-- like this--in case they got what you're looking for attached to a string.  See what I mean, Purser?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Hello, young fellow!

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Coming to the pool for a swim?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Nooooo!--going to catch up on my reading.  I'll take this one.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Wouldn't bet against her.  Tell you what I will do--bet you I find that bracelet before we hit France.  Not a hundred, though--just fifty.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: It's a bet--come on, Sally!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Nice girl, that--  I'd hate to see <U>her</U> get a raw deal.  You know, the great trouble with crooks is they're <U>too</U> smart. Now if I'd taken that bracelet, I'd find some way to slip it back--I'd know I could never get ashore with it.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Anybody that's taken the trouble to get it would be a mug to put it back.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Thought you might need me--don't talk, kid, and don't let him scare you--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Don't be too smart, Jimmy--you're out in the rough yourself. You had an argument with Lother a couple of hours before he was killed--but I'll deal with that later--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Don't get yourself all worked up--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: You keep out of this--  You admit you thought of killing him--how were you going to do it?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Mmmmmmmmmhm....  Now, Jimmy, what were you doing in that corridor before the shots were fired?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Why, I--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Here's your fifty.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Thanks. That makes us square.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Their faces are familiar--but not to each other.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Now that that's settled, why not make the game a foursome?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: No--I'll take Sally and give you the best of it.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Tell you what I'll do.  I'll toss you for her--heads she plays with me.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: O.K. Heads you win.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: I'm O.K. It didn't hurt much.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: That's all right. I'll attend to this.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Wait a minute--let's match for it.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Never mind--I'll pay for it now. It'll save time.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Oh, Denby--have you seen Sally around?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: No--I'm looking for Miss Marsh myself. I thought you might know where she is--

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: She was to meet me here--why don't you wait? She ought to be here any minute.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I would--but our rehearsal starts right away.  Before I go I want to ask you a little favor. Sally is an important part of my show. Some day--not now--when you get a chance--let her come to just one rehearsal. I'll appreciate it.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I don't know what it is, but I won't use it.  Is she entertaining you?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: I should say not.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Good!  At last you're making yourself useful. So long!

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I won't--I'll ask for one right now.  Sally tells me she's in love with you.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: She did?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yes--but don't ask me why--because I could never tell you. I don't know what most guys want out of life--but <U>that</U> would be enough for me--I wouldn't care about-- easy money--or--showing off my smart brains--I'd just like to live <U>my</U> life so nothing I did would bounce back and ruin <U>hers</U>--Do I make myself clear?

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: Very clear. That's one favor I'll be glad to do you.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: O.K., kid--  I'm only sorry for one thing.

turns.speaker: BRETT
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: If you hadn't agreed--I was going to throw you overboard--

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Here you are, sir.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: What'll I say?

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Eighty cents a word--three--six--nine words. That'll be seven twenty, but it's too much--I'll show you how to save some money.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Where do you live?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: In New York.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Your wife knows that, don't she?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Then you don't have to tell her--cut out New York.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: "Will be back in four weeks"--  --that saves you eighty cents right there!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: That's right--here's the eighty cents for you. I'd rather see you get it than the company--send it right off.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Wait a minute--I think I can cut out a couple o' more words.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: "Will--be--back--in--four--weeks." You don't need the "will be." Just say "Back in four weeks."

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: That's right. I owe you a dollar sixty.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Wait a minute--I think I can cut something else out.  "Back in four weeks." Instead of "in four weeks"--say "next month"--That saves another word.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Right. Here's eighty cents. Send it.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Just a minute--I don't think we need the word "Back" --Where <U>is</U> "Back"?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Back is in New York.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Your wife knows that, don't she?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Cut it out.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Now we get it down to two words--"next month."

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Send that.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Wait a minute--What <U>is</U> next month?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Next month is June.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Fine! Instead of saying "next month"--we'll use one word and say "June."

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: June? That's my wife's name.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: That's great! There's the address and message all in one word.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: O.K.! Send that!

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Just a minute--Your wife knows her own name, doesn't she?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: SHORTIE
turns.text: Well, there's no use in sending it.  See that--I saved you seven twenty!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Well. I'd rather see <U>you</U> get it than the company.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: I'll say--how fast is this boat going?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Oh,--we're doing about thirty--

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Pretty good--thirty <U>miles</U> an hour--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: No. <U>Knots</U>!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Knots!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: I can see you're no gentleman--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: That's me!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Not the <U>real</U> Chad Denby?--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yes--Me--in person!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: So what?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I can see where I won't talk much to you.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: <U>Nuts</U> to you too!

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Hello, Denby!

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I thought I put you to bed.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Oh, was that me you put to bed? Thanks. I've been looking all over for you.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Well, did you find me?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Not yet.  Say, where is this boat headed for?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: This is a fine time to be asking that. You're on your way to France.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: That's news to me. I'd better cable my wife.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Hey, boy--give this man a cablegram blank.  Where is your wife?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: She's in New York.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Tell her you're on your way to France and will be back in four weeks.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: That's fine.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Come on, get up.  That horse is carrying too much of a load.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Who won?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Well, you got the first down--there's one more to go. Come on, we're ready to start right now. Come on. Just keep stiff.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: I was never stiffer in my life.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: All right, folks, get on your mark. When you hear the pistol shot--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's funny--maybe you can use him in the show, Mr. Denby.

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: <U>Denby!</U>--Are you Chad Denby?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, there you are--

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: That's right--you're the one I was looking for.  You'll excuse me.   How about you and I being alone?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Not now, Toots--Which is the right way to say this? You're dumber than me--or--you're dumber than I?

turns.speaker: DAN
turns.text: Let me see now--Don't tell me--  You're dumber than me and I'm dumber than you. I don't get it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Never mind.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: McKinney's the name.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Miss Marsh.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Here we are, folks--eighty thousand wild-eyed fans go mad--they go mad as Chad Denby--with the arms of iron, and the nerves of steel--picks up his racket--  What is this thing--a racket or a mallet?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Looks to me like standard equipment for the Department of Street Cleaning--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Too bad we're not making a trip around the world-- maybe we could finish this game.  Hey! When you get through with that conference, shoot that last disk!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: You can always tell how much a man's traveled by the way he plays shuffle-board.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yeah--if he'd only stick to shuffle-board.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Those kids seem to be getting along fine!--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: It must be the sea air--it gets everybody.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: He's a likable chap--he's got an honest face--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: It's all right--if you like honest faces--let's have another drink--Steward!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Oh no--I don't want to impose on you--  It's funny about that billfold--I could have sworn I had it-

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Hello, Inspector--I hear your vacation's been spoiled. Somebody lost a bracelet.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Yes, a bracelet's been lost, but I'm still on my vacation.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I understand you searched Brett for it last night. By the way--what do you know about him?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Well, I've seen him here and there. What's on your mind?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Oh, nothing--only I wondered why you suspected him.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you--we picked him up about a year ago-- but could never pin anything on him.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Maybe he just travels in bad company.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Yeah--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I didn't--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: He asked for a loan of it, didn't he?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yes--but I didn't give it to him--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Is this your gun?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Well, that's something--even if only the fish can see it.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Are you happy?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Will be--as soon as the ship sails.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Am I a member of this club?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: You're the President. Come in! Your brother was just telling me a few jokes I can use on the radio--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Are you paying any attention to his jokes?--the first thing you know, you'll be taking piano lessons from Venus de Milo--  Get out of here.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Everything O.K.?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Just what the doctor ordered.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Looks like your old workshop back on 42nd Street.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Like it?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Swell--You've got Times Square right here--all but the noises--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yep--spending lots of time aboard--you see, Sally, I sold this Transatlantic idea to the shipping company.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: And you've put it over--haven't you?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Why not? I give 'em a great show--and you know-- We're doing capacity, Sally--and all <U>Nice</U> people--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You never fail at anything, do you, Chad?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: No--not much--excepting--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Still got my picture, I see--I was pretty dumb then, wasn't I, Chad?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: No--Inexperienced--  A red-headed kid--homemade clothes--Broadway was Paradise--and a slot at the Automat was a Banquet.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I came to tell you what a swell guy I think you are to do this--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Do what--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You made it possible for us to get away at a few hours' notice--you never asked why, but I guess you know.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: News travels fast on Broadway--you had to get away from a rat--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: It wasn't only that--Ned was in a jam.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I get it--Lee Lother have a hand in that, too?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I was so crazy about him--anything he did or said was O.K. by me.  I introduced him to people--even after I knew his stock promoting was phoney and the card games were crooked. It didn't seem to matter--I didn't care--  --until he roped Ned in. Some confidence game--and the kid left his fingerprints on a drinking glass.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I felt pretty low, Sally, when I heard you were running around with a racketeer--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Women have a curious taste for knickknacks. When I found out about Ned--tried to make a break--Lee wouldn't stand for it and--well--here I am!

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Stay on the other side of the pond for a couple of months--you'll soon forget all about it.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Chad Denby broadcasting--  --the nicest man I ever knew--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: But not nice enough to marry--eh?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Come on, now--you've forgotten all about that.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I'll never love anybody else.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Women are such fools!--Why do so many of us pass up <U>right</U> guys?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Guess they're dull--nothing for you to reform.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You're just a Master of Ceremonies. He might have knocked his head off.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: What's the difference? He's got more heads than he needs.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I don't get the humor of that remark.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: <U>He</U> does. Here's your quarter, Brett.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Very serious?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Very--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Why--don't you like him?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Of course--but--  There's your cue--hurry up--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I'll give you another chance to tell the truth, Lother.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Why don't you be a good little boy and leave her alone?

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Oh--I understand you were an important part of her education when she came to New York.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: I just tried to show her the difference between the squirrels and the skunks.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Meaning what?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: You don't shoot squirrels.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Yep--everybody's having a good time but me--What do you want, Mary?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I just wrote a poem about the Atlantic Ocean--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: But, Mary--everybody's having such a great time-- why spoil it?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Somebody's got to do it--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Well, let's hear the poem--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, you dear Atlantic Ocean--how you spread across the sea--From New York to dear old Europe--just for boats to ride on thee--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Very good, Mary--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But I'm not finished yet----And your waves are so colossal--rocking boats both to and fro--Oh-h, Atlantic, how I love you ----how I love you--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: What's the matter, Mary?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm getting seasick--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: H'mm--<U>Dear</U> Atlantic--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Mr. Denby--What do you think I ought to do with that part?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Put the whole thing in an envelope and mail it through a porthole--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Den-n-by!

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Everyone but me--what do you want now, Mary?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I feel better now--I've got a riddle! When is a plate of bean soup not a plate of bean soup?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: All right. When <U>is</U> a plate of bean soup not a plate of noodle soup?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: When it falls off the table and turns turtle--Cute?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Mary--fall off the boat and turn to the left--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: With your dry wit and humor--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Oh yeah?--My personality put this thing over--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maurice Chevalier! There's a fellow with personality.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: What's he got that I haven't got?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well, he has a straw hat--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: So have I--I can get it right out of my trunk.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: --And he has sex appeal.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: So what?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Get that out of your trunk.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: All right--don't spoil the trip with any of those jokes-- there's a nice bunch of people on this trip--nothing but class--I looked over the passenger list and they're all members of the Who's Who!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Never mind the Who's Who--Before I get on this boat I want to know What's What! How about my raise? All I get out of these ocean trips is dizzy.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Don't blame it on the ocean!--All right, you'll get the raise!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Is that one of the Who's Who?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: No--He's probably one of the "Here's How."  Take it easy--the ocean's pretty rough today--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: H'mm ... no wonder I have trouble rounding up this show--Don't you know there's a rehearsal going on?-- And you wanted a raise.--Come on--get going or you'll get it!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, all right--  See you later, Toots.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Chad--what about the rest of the show?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Oh,--I was having so much fun I almost forgot--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Denby, I wrote a poem about a bracelet--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Good-night, folks.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Then, after the first number, I tell the one about the Scotchman trying to open a Pullman window--the Scotchman says to the window--"Gee you're tight."-- and the window says--"You loosen up a bit and so will I."--Good?--And then I do the one--  Oh--you don't like it, eh?

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: Chad--Lother's on the boat, and I'm worried sick about Sally--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Oh!--So that's it. Does she know he's on board?

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: No--but I'm going to keep my eye on--

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: What happened to you?

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: You've got a gun, haven't you, Chad? Will you let me have it?

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: Don't ask any questions--just give it to me.

turns.speaker: DENBY
turns.text: Easy kid--easy....  Come on--I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: You're wasting your time--she's a friend of mine.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: Eh?... Oh.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: He works the boats as a "come-on" man. We ought to make a fair combination and do a little business. Jack's a pretty good dealer himself.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: There's a lot of trout in this stream just waitin' for a fly.  I've already been workin' on a young fellow from Chicago--related to one of the big packin' families--on his way to Biarritz for a good time. Likes a little game of bridge and poker.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: That's him! That's the sucker!!

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Looks lonesome--Bring him over here.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Can you read 'em Jack?

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: They're a cinch to read--Queen of Clubs--  --Ace of Diamonds.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: The man that marks them is an artist--two hundred and fifty bucks for six decks--and they're worth it.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: The country boy's about due.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Better unlock the door.  Sit up, darling, and be dignified.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: Out my way in Montana we always call a bluff.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Well, I helped my hand so I'll have to see you.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: How much did you lose?

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: About twelve hundred.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: I went for four.

turns.speaker: SUMMERS
turns.text: It's a long trip and we'll get that sucker later.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: All right--but what is there to face? It's finished.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: You ran away because you were afraid. I don't want it to end like that.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I didn't want to see you again--that's my privilege.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: It wasn't smart. Even if you'd gotten away without me --I'd have found you--no matter where you were.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Why don't you leave me alone?

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Because I want you--will always want you--no other woman'll ever take your place.  I want you more now than I did that first night--  You've forgotten all that, I suppose?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I wish I could.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Get wise to yourself, Sally--you're no sob story.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You get wise to <U>yourself</U>! If you know what's good for you, you'll leave me alone. Everybody's entitled to one mistake--Well--you're mine. When the going got too rough, I pulled up stakes and quit. We stay quit!--Get that!--And what're you going to do about it?

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: That's more like the old Sally--a little bit of fire.  How about Ned?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: He's all right.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Thanks to me.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You leave the kid alone.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: A tipoff in the right quarter to take his fingerprints and--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: --you'd go with him!

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Don't kid yourself--you know how I stand back there.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Not because of Ned.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Of course not--  --but isn't it a coincidence that he's from the eighteenth precinct--where they made the squawk?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You can't bluff me any more.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I'm crazy about the kid and I got him into it.  What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Just smile again and be reasonable.  I'll order dinner here--just the two of us--like old times.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: --and you swear when you get to the other side, you'll never come near either of us again?

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: That's a bet--but I couldn't let you walk out like that, Sally. I'd have gone cuckoo back there--just thinking about you--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Don't, Lee--that's dead.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Let's see if I can bring it back to life.

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Go ahead--you didn't used to be so fussy--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I've lost my taste for knickknacks--

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: Don't be a mug all your life--I'm trying to help you-- you need me more than I need you--have you figured they might pick the kid up in France and extradite him?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Have you ever figured they might extradite you?

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: I'm not so clumsy with fingerprints--

turns.speaker: LOTHER
turns.text: I know he is. You change those clothes and then come to my cabin. I'll expect you around twelve o'clock.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Not a chance--I'm through.

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: Yes, Yes!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: You didn't have a gun in your hand last night?

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: S'pose you've never thought of killing him--

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: I wouldn't say that--  I'm glad he's dead--yes--I'd thought of killing him-- but I didn't--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: Because I was yellow, I guess--

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: I tried to borrow a gun from Chad, but--

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: This is interesting--  Why didn't you tell me you gave this kid your gun last night?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: It's getting kind of chilly on deck. If you'll excuse me, I think I'll go to bed. Good night, Mr. McKinney!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Good night!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Congratulations.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Exciting, wasn't it? Where's Jimmy?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: He'll be back.  What would you do if anybody gave you a bracelet?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Say, "Thanks very much!"

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I mean if you knew it were stolen.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Well, of course, I wouldn't take it.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: And if you liked the person, you'd naturally persuade him to give it back and go straight, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Sure I would--but I don't get what you're driving at.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Maybe you will after you've thought it over.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: That's the truth--every single word!

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I sincerely hope so--

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Why should <U>I</U> kill him?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: For a very excellent reason from your own admission--  --I'm not saying you <U>did</U>--but I think you know more than you're telling. Years of experience have taught me to mistrust circumstantial evidence. Nevertheless, in your case there's plenty of it.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Soon as I get that bracelet back I'm going to relax. Wish the guy that borrowed it would help me out--I got to win that fifty bucks.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I've got a hunch you're going to win that bet, Inspector.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: I hope so. Well, I guess you two can do without me. I'll be seeing you.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Next time I get a vacation I'll spend it at headquarters. Good-night.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: He's a swell person. He told me he'd rather turn one guy straight than jug a million.

turns.speaker: PURSER
turns.text: There you are, sir.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PURSER
turns.text: Thirty one's and two ten's?

turns.speaker: PURSER
turns.text: He's certainly good-natured.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: "Smooth's" the word.

turns.speaker: PURSER
turns.text: I mean--a lot of gentlemen would be offended if you searched them like that.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: It all depends on what you're used to.

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Well, I'll be a son of a sea cook!

turns.speaker: PURSER
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: MCKINNEY
turns.text: Nothin--  --I just remembered the name of a guy that owes me fifty bucks.

turns.speaker: NED
turns.text: I thought I had our sailing covered up--  --and here it is.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Do you think Lother could have seen it?
